children.subject: Thanks for the comment! Yeah, that was my original plan. Did you take CS 61B with CS 70? If you did, how was the workload like? If not, what other students talk about the workload? I have finished a data structure class at my community college and have taken all the math classes up to Diff Eq.

It's a lot of work and stress for LSCS to take CS 61B and CS 70 together, but it's still doable if you have nothing much that you wanna do on campus. But I would suggest someone to take it over two semesters and take some electives with those two
^ I am not the first anon btw

I am first Anon, I did not but I took 61C and 70 together later, both needed for my declaration so it was still stressful. Most of my friends took 61B and 70 together. I would say it's going to be a stressful semester due to sheer workload. If you can read some of the notes for 70 over summer, I would do that too. Most people, not just transfers, need to take two hard techs together, be it 61B and C, 61B and 70, or 61C and 70. Since it's not required for your declaration, I would see about taking 61B with something like an AC course and then 61C and 70 together and just sacrifice some of your 61C time for 70 if needed. You will declare at the end of your first year still, and this gives you an option to early declare after fall if you get an A- and a B+ in 61A/B. You could also think about taking 61B and 61C together, they do not build off of each other.
Thanks, all. How about taking CS61B with EE16A?

I did that, I took 61B, 16A and 54 together. I did not think it was too intense, but I also did not get the best grades. Definitely doable since EE16A does not have projects and what have you, and is not too time consuming outside of homeworks.
CS 61B and EE 16A is doable cuz EE 16A is not hard if you know linear algebra and circuits
Do not recommend 61B and 61C together if you care about your 61B grade. 61C is heavily project-based, but it would be a good pair with CS 70
So it seems like I can take CS 61B and CS 70 separately. But the disadvantage of doing that is I have to take three upper division CS classes to graduate in 2 years. Hmm.

If you really want to graduate in 2 years, then you should take CS 61B with CS 70 together, or just take 47B with CS 70 in the fall and hope that CS 61A and CS 70 will give you a 3.30 GPA. I believe there are ways to graduate in 2.5 years as LSCS if you want to take that extra time. Good luck!
Yeah, you need to have a semester where you take 3 upper divs at once. If you can, you can also take one over the summer next year but most likely you'll be trying to get an internship.
Take 61A over the summer and take 61B and 70 together in the fall. This is what a lot of transfers do who want to declare by the end of their first semester

history.content:
Declaring by the end of the first year is not only possible, but probably necessary, in order to finish the major on time.

Have you made a two-year plan to start getting an idea of what sorts of schedules you should be looking at?

children.subject:
61B and 70 were commonly taken before the change in the GPA cutoff (in that most students did this, while others did 61C + 70, which is roughly the same difficulty). Taking them together is fine.

To be clear, is Fall 2017 your first or second semester? You have to declare by the end of your second semester.

Declaring later means that you'll go longer with having low course registration priority.

Fall 2017 is my first semester. So it seems like I can take CS 61B and CS 70 separately. But the disadvantage of doing that is I have to take three upper division CS classes to graduate in 2 years. Hmm.

Ah, I think I misunderstood your question. You were asking if second semester was considered late, not if it was early.

It is neither late nor early.

Taking three CS upper divs in the same semester is also not uncommon. I believe transfer students take 3 technicals in most semesters (since 5-ish lower divs + 7 upper divs divided by 4 semesters).
Thank you, Steven! Now, it's much clear what to expect at Cal.

@Steven Bi Yes, I have made my two-year plan. I was thinking of declaring CS at the end of Fall 17. But, I am concerned about the workload and difficulties of CS61B & 70 together. So can I declare my major at the end of Spring 18 instead? If I can, what are the pros and cons of declaring a little later from a student's perspective? 

@Nicole Evans McIntyre Yes, I have completed CS61A at Laney. Actually, I finished all the CS61 series at community colleges (DVC and Laney) But, I want to improve my data structure skills by taking CS61B in the Fall. How's the GPA calculation work in my case? What I've heard from the advisors so far is that I must take either CS 61A and/or B along with CS70 to declare L&S CS.

I am a transfer and I took all 61 series (I actually only had taken 61B equivalent, but I decided to take 61B here for P/NP). I actually learned quite a lot of new stuff, but I am sure it's nothing that you can't learn it yourself. I would say they are all worthy of my time because the materials that you learn at CC just can't compare to what you will learn here. The lower divisions CS classes here are meant to prepare you for upper divisions, but again, it's not something that you can't learn yourself.

Thank you so much for your comments! I'm still debating whether I should take CS61 series again or not. If there's any transfer student out there, what do you think about taking CS61 series again at Cal? Is it worth reviewing what I studied at community colleges? I must admit that the CS courses I took at my community college were not that challenging, comparing to the 61 series at Cal.

history.content:
Hi, I'm Jo. I was wondering incoming junior transfers could declare L&S CS by the end of the second semester at Cal.

I was thinking of taking both CS61B and CS70 over Fall 2017, but I've heard that they are both challenging classes and I'd like to take each one with a thorough understanding of the materials.

Thanks in advance!
history.subject: Incoming Junior Transfers Declaring L&S CS by Their First or Second Semester?
